2: Have you ever worked on a project where you sometimes hack around in a submodule, commit, forget about it.
3: And then go back to your top level project, and after some time
5: If you have worked with submodules, then you know that now the build will fail - it'll be unable to pull the submodul
6: e. You should have done a
in the submodule too, before you pushed the top level project! Otherwise the sub
7: module pointer would have moved to your new stuff in the submodule, but these changes would not be
8: yone else, since you forgot to push them.

10: This small script is a reminder for such situations.
12: (my fav shortcut for "push origin master") which launches this script, you'll get inf
13: ormed if you're about to make this silly mistake :-)
17: to your project and run the following commands:
23: # if you just want to ignore this file in one of your projects, use this:
29: # or you can do the same to your ~/.gitignore file :-)
30: # You'll need to add the following to your ~/.gitconfig file for this to work:
34: git config alias.pom '!./check_submodules_reachable.rb && git push origin master'
